title: Elham Valley Way Walking Route

images.title: David Anstiss / View from the Elham Valley Way
images.caption: View form the Elham Valley Way. On a footpath near Green Hills. Looking down the valley towards Canterbury. The red tiled houses in the background are on the Street in Kingston.

images.title: David Anstiss / Bridge on Elham Valley Way
images.caption: Bridge on the trail. The long distance walk heads over a farm bridge (over the River Nailbourne) in a sheep pasture near Bourne House, the path leads towards Bourne Park Road.

images.title: Nick Smith / Stile on the Elham Valley Way
images.caption: This part of the Elham Valley Way is shared with the North Downs Way and The Saxon Shore way which might explain all the arrows on the stile post.

images.title: Nick Smith / Looking NE towards Elham along Elham Valley Way
images.caption: One of the few sections with any protection from the weather, although not huge, the trees provide quite a bit of shelter.

images.title: Nick Smith / Small section of cover on the Elham Valley Way
images.caption: Small section of cover on the trail. This small tree covered section is one of the few areas of shelter on the Elham to Lyminge part of the walk, it was most welcome on the day the photo was taken as it offered reasonable protection from the rain.

images.title: Nick Smith / Bridge House on the Elham Valley Way
images.caption: Just before reaching Shuttlesfield Lane the footpath passes beside the house.

images.title: Nick Smith / Looking SW along the Elham Valley Way
images.caption: The trail follows the Nailbourne river through the valley at this point.

images.title: Nick Smith / View of Newbarn from the Elham Valley Way
images.caption: View of Newbarn from the trail

description: Explore the Kent Downs Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty on this delightful walk through Kent. The route starts on the coast at Hythe and heads north to Canterbury via Elham and Barham. Highlights on the route include stretches through the seabrook valley near Hythe, ancient woodland (dating from before the 17th century), beautiful orchards, views of the Nailbourne river and the famous Cathedral at Canterbury at the end of the route. The walk runs for a distance of about 22 miles with some moderate climbs along the way.
